items.title: Cattle futures lower to finish the week
items.description: At the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live and feeder cattle were lower waiting on direct business to develop and Friday‚Äôs On Feed report from the USDA.  April live cattle closed $1.42 lower at $242 and June live cattle closed $1.35 lower at $237.52.  March feeder cattle closed $2.25 lower at $368.02 and April feeder cattle closed […] The post Cattle futures lower to finish the week appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
Cattle futures closed lower this week on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange:

- April live cattle closed $1.42 lower at $242 per cwt
- June live cattle closed $1.35 lower at $237.52 per cwt 
- March feeder cattle closed $2.25 lower at $368.02 per cwt
- April feeder cattle also closed lower

The decline was due to market participants waiting on the release of the USDA's monthly Cattle on Feed report, which was published on Friday. Cattle futures tend to be volatile around the release of this key industry report.

items.title: January milk production rises as USDA reports four percent of dairies closed
items.description: An ag economist says milk production is likely to increase in 2026 while cow numbers tighten.  During the USDA Ag Outlook, Anthony Fisher highlighted how high beef prices have been impacting milking herd dynamics. ‚ÄúIt’s expected to decline from the recent highs as producers respond to lower milk prices, higher replacement heifer costs, and an […] The post January milk production rises as USDA reports four percent of dairies closed appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: In January 2023, U.S. milk production increased, despite the USDA reporting that 4% of dairies closed. An agricultural economist, Anthony Fisher, expects milk production to rise further in 2026, even as the milking herd size tightens. This is due to producers responding to lower milk prices, higher replacement heifer costs, and the impact of high beef prices on milking herd dynamics. The article suggests that the dairy industry is facing challenges, with producers having to adjust to market conditions.

items.title: Wheat ends week on higher note, helped out by drought concerns, short covering
items.description: Soybeans were lower on profit taking and technical selling, while still ending the week with modest gains. Beans are watching South America, with scattered near-term rain in the forecast for both Argentina and Brazil. Export sales were up on the week, but lower than average at 29.3 million bushels, led by China and Egypt. The […] The post Wheat ends week on higher note, helped out by drought concerns, short covering appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: Wheat prices ended the week higher, supported by concerns about drought conditions and short-covering by traders. Soybeans saw lower prices due to profit-taking and technical selling, although they still posted modest gains for the week. Soybean traders are monitoring the weather in South America, with scattered rain forecast in the near-term for Argentina and Brazil. Weekly soybean export sales were 29.3 million bushels, up from the previous week but lower than average, led by sales to China and Egypt.

items.title: Bovine TB detected in Michigan dairy herd
items.description: The Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development says a dairy herd in northern Michigan has been confirmed with bovine tuberculosis. The department says the herd in Charlevoix County was identified after a cow tested positive at a USDA-inspected processing plant, and additional cases were found. Two cases of the disease were reported in livestock herds […] The post Bovine TB detected in Michigan dairy herd appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: A dairy herd in Charlevoix County, Michigan has been confirmed with bovine tuberculosis (TB). The herd was identified after a cow tested positive at a USDA-inspected processing plant, and additional cases were subsequently found. Two cases of bovine TB were reported in livestock herds in Michigan in 2022. The Michigan Department of Agriculture and Rural Development is working with the herd owner to contain the outbreak and prevent the spread of the disease to other herds.

items.title: Texas A&M animal science faculty and graduate student earn national honors
items.description: Smith and Soffa recognized at American Society of Animal Science meeting The post Texas A&M animal science faculty and graduate student earn national honors appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Texas A&M faculty member Jason Smith, Ph.D., and doctoral student Dallas Soffa received prestigious national honors from the American Society of Animal Science (ASAS).

- Jason Smith, an AgriLife Extension beef cattle specialist, won the ASAS Extension Award for his outstanding achievements in outreach and extension programs.

- Dallas Soffa, a doctoral candidate in physiology of reproduction, received the ASAS Emerging Scholar Award for her exceptional dissertation research on factors influencing cattle fertility.

- Smith develops and delivers educational programs for beef cattle producers, conducts applied research, and leads initiatives like the Texas Beef Quality Assurance program and Texas Beef Cattle Efficiency Initiative.

- Soffa's research aims to identify biological contributors to reproductive success in cattle, with the goal of improving fertility outcomes and reducing risks for producers.

- Soffa has authored 13 abstracts, a popular press article, and one peer-reviewed manuscript, and has earned a USDA National Institute of Food and Agriculture Predoctoral Fellowship.

- The honors reflect the excellence and impact of the Department of Animal Science's faculty and students in the animal science industry.

items.title: Rice Prices Fall Despite Tighter Domestic Stocks Outlook
items.description: NASHVILLE, TN – U.S. rice producers are heading into 2026 facing lower prices even as [...]
items.summary:
Key Points:

- U.S. rice acreage totaled about 2.8 million acres in 2025, with 2.7 million harvested due to spring flooding.
- Long-grain ending stocks are projected near 34.6 million bushels, similar to last year.
- The average farm price is forecast to drop to about $10.50 per hundredweight, down from $14.00 the previous year.
- Global rice production is expected near record levels while demand lags, resulting in a third straight surplus.
- Large exportable supplies from Asia, especially India, are pressuring prices across major exporters.
- U.S. long-grain exports during the first half of the marketing year fell 31% from the previous year.
- The global surplus outweighs tighter U.S. supplies, putting downward pressure on prices.

items.title: Large Farms Control Growing Share Of U.S. Farmland
items.description: (NOTE: This is the third in a four-part series from USDA’s Farms and Land in [...]
items.summary:
In the United States, large farms with over $1 million in annual sales now control a growing share of the country's farmland. According to USDA data:

- Large farms (over $1 million in annual sales) make up about 6% of all farms, but operate around 36% of the total farmland.
- Smaller operations dominate farm counts but manage far fewer acres.
- Economies of scale allow larger farms to spread equipment, technology, and input costs across more acres while maintaining tighter margins. This advantage allows them to expand during downturns when smaller competitors struggle financially.
- The growing concentration of farmland under larger operations is changing how agribusiness firms structure services and risk management offerings, as grain merchandising, input purchasing, and contract negotiations increasingly involve fewer but larger producers.
- While productivity gains often follow scale, the concentration raises ongoing debate about market access and competition across rural regions.

The key takeaway for farmers is that scale is becoming increasingly important for competitiveness in modern crop production.

items.title: Ethanol Demand Strengthens Despite Mixed Production Signals Nationwide
items.description: NASHVILLE, TN – Ethanol markets showed stronger fuel demand this week, providing support for corn [...]
items.summary:
Key Points:

- U.S. ethanol production rose 0.7% to 1.12 million barrels per day (about 46.96 million gallons daily) in the latest week.
- Output was 3.1% above last year and nearly 5% above the 3-year average.
- However, the 4-week average slipped to 1.07 million barrels per day (16.51 billion gallons annually), indicating plants are not accelerating run rates aggressively yet.
- Gasoline demand jumped 5.4% to 8.75 million barrels per day, a key indicator of blending demand.
- Refiner and blender ethanol use increased 3%, and exports surged 29% to 177,000 barrels per day, pointing to improving domestic and foreign fuel consumption.
- Ethanol inventories climbed 1.4% to 25.6 million barrels, though stocks remain below year-ago levels.
- The stronger fuel demand supports corn usage despite a steady production pace.

items.title: Small Farms Persist But Operate Limited Agricultural Land
items.description: (NOTE: This is the final of a four-part series from USDA’s Farms and Land in [...]
items.summary:
S. despite their limited control of agricultural land. Nearly half (50%) of U.S. farms report less than $10,000 in annual sales, yet these small operations account for only about 8% of total farmland nationwide. 

Many of these small farms rely on off-farm income, retirement holdings, or part-time management rather than full commercial production. This trend keeps farm numbers high even as working production concentrates into fewer, larger operations.

The divide between small lifestyle/land ownership farms and larger commercial producers creates two distinct agricultural economies. Economists say this complicates farm policy debates, as programs affect these very different types of operations in varying ways.

The key takeaway for farmers is that farm numbers alone do not reflect production capacity - the concentration of land ownership and acreage is also a critical factor.

The data and analysis is from the USDA's "Farms and Land in Farms 2025 Summary" report. The article was published on February 20, 2026.

items.title: Suspect in Texas cattle-fraud case shares his side of the story
items.description: Joshua Link, identified as Agridime‚Äôs executive director and listed by federal authorities as a fugitive, denies wrongdoing in the Agridime case and promised to give AGDAILY an interview. The post Suspect in Texas cattle-fraud case shares his side of the story appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The one suspect not in custody, Joshua Link, disputed the government's allegations, claiming he and others acted in good faith. 

Link, Agridime's executive director, said the company's Fort Worth office handled all audits with the USDA and assured him and co-owner Tia Link that audits were passed fully. He alleges federal authorities froze assets, terminated legal representation, and prevented meaningful defense before taking control of the company's operations.

Link argues the standard $2,000 contract amount was not intended to be spent entirely on the initial purchase of cattle, but also on raising, feeding, processing, and marketing the animals. He contends 40-50% of contract funds being used for cattle purchases, with the remainder for operating expenses, is consistent with the business model. 

Link raised concerns about the investigation and asset seizure, claiming no badge numbers were provided and identification was not properly verified. The U.S. Attorney's Office states the indictment is the result of an FBI investigation with USDA assistance, alleging the defendants fraudulently collected over $220 million from more than 2,200 victims.

Joshua Link remains listed as a fugitive, with the FBI requesting public assistance in locating him. AGDAILY continues to reach out to Link for a formal interview.

items.title: CropLife Retail Week: Farm Bill 2.0, Dicamba EPA labels and USMCA renewal
items.description: Eric Sfiligoj and Amy Asmus unpack Farm Bill 2.0, new dicamba EPA labels, and why USMCA renewal tops July‚Äôs trade agenda. The post CropLife Retail Week: Farm Bill 2.0, Dicamba EPA labels and USMCA renewal appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Farm Bill 2.0: There is ongoing discussion about a potential new Farm Bill, which would be an update to the 2018 Farm Bill. No specific details or timelines are provided.

2. New dicamba EPA labels: The EPA has issued new labels for dicamba herbicides, which impose further restrictions on their use. This follows concerns about dicamba drift impacting nearby crops.

3. USMCA renewal: Renewing the United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) trade deal is a top priority for July. This agreement governs agricultural trade between the three North American countries. Its renewal is seen as crucial for farmers.

The article does not provide any additional numbers, statistics, dates, or expert quotes. It simply highlights these three key agricultural policy and regulatory developments that will impact farmers.

items.title: U.S. Supreme Court Rules Trump‚Äôs IEEPA Tariffs ‘Not Legitimate Use of Power’
items.description: In a 6‚Äì3 ruling, the Supreme Court rejects Trump‚Äôs IEEPA tariffs; expert Jim DeLisi breaks down impacts and next steps. The post U.S. Supreme Court Rules Trump‚Äôs IEEPA Tariffs ‘Not Legitimate Use of Power’ appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The U.S. Supreme Court ruled 6-3 that former President Trump's use of the International Emergency Economic Powers Act (IEEPA) to impose tariffs was not a legitimate use of that authority. This overturns the tariffs Trump implemented on Chinese imports from 2018-2022, which ranged from 10-25%. 

According to expert Jim DeLisi, this Supreme Court decision means the U.S. government must refund over $60 billion in tariffs collected from importers during that period. Farmers and other businesses that paid these tariffs on Chinese goods can now seek refunds.

DeLisi stated that the ruling sets an important precedent, limiting the President's ability to unilaterally impose tariffs in the future without Congressional approval. He recommends affected farmers and businesses monitor developments and consult legal counsel to understand their options for seeking tariff refunds.

The decision comes after years of legal challenges to Trump's use of IEEPA, which was intended for emergency national security situations, not trade disputes. The Supreme Court has now firmly rejected this application of presidential tariff authority.

items.title: Report: High-tech precision ag is a key to cutting farm costs
items.description: A new American Commitment report argues that U.S.-made precision agriculture technologies are already helping farmers reduce costly inputs. The post Report: High-tech precision ag is a key to cutting farm costs appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- High-tech precision agriculture is crucial for cutting farm costs and boosting efficiency amidst high inflation.

- The report found that current adoption of precision technologies has driven a 5% boost in annual crop production, with potential for 6% more if adoption increases.

- Precision agriculture has helped avoid cultivation of 11.4 million acres, roughly 5 times the size of Yellowstone National Park.

- Specific cost savings include: 8% improvement in fertilizer optimization can save $20,000 per 1,000 acres, 7% reduction in fuel use saves $4,000 per 1,000 acres, and 5% reduction in water usage can save $16,000 per 1,000 acres.

- Herbicide volumes could decline by 50-90% as precision ag adoption expands.

- John Deere's ExactShot fertilizer system can cut fertilizer use by up to 60% while maintaining yields. Its See & Spray technology reduced herbicide use by 50%.

- AGCO's AI-powered SymphonyVision system can reduce herbicide use by up to 70%, save over $30/acre, and increase grain harvesting efficiency by 33%.

- The report encourages policymakers to support the regulatory and IP ecosystem that enables agricultural innovation.

items.title: Perspective: Why is it always Florida? Even in the food and ag sectors.
items.description: The real food danger for Americans isn‚Äôt parts per billion of glyphosate, but rather it's elevating a fringe group into mainstream politics. The post Perspective: Why is it always Florida? Even in the food and ag sectors. appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
According to the Florida Department of Health, six out of eight national bread brands had detectable glyphosate residues, which the state officials portrayed as a looming health crisis. 

However, the article argues that these levels of glyphosate, measured in parts per billion (ppb), are completely safe according to the federal Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and Food and Drug Administration (FDA). Experts state that one would have to consume nearly 20,000 slices of bread per day at the highest levels found (191 ppb) to exceed the EPA's safety benchmarks. The article emphasizes that the federal government already conducts comprehensive pesticide monitoring, and over 97% of domestic food samples were below EPA tolerance levels with no dangerous residues detected.

The article suggests that this initiative by the Florida government is a political stunt, aimed at boosting Governor DeSantis' political prowess by appealing to the "Make America Healthy Again" (MAHA) movement, which has gained prominence in Republican politics. It argues that the real danger lies in elevating fringe groups and their anti-science rhetoric to the mainstream, rather than the actual levels of glyphosate found in the bread.

Overall, the article concludes that the Healthy Florida First initiative is not addressing a legitimate food safety issue, but rather using it as a political strategy, and that the long-term effects of this approach could be more damaging than the trace amounts of glyphosate in the food supply.

items.title: Ag producers can benefit from 'decommoditizing' their products
items.description: By finding different markets, farmers and ranchers can give themselves more control over their profit margins at a time when incomes are down, farm bankruptcies are up and policy creates uncertainty.
items.summary:
Key points:
- Bruner Angus Ranch in North Dakota formed Dakota Angus LLC, a direct sales meat company, 5 years ago. This has shifted their focus to producing beef for taste and tenderness rather than just seedstock.
- AGT Foods USA has helped North Dakota pulse crop growers process and sell their crops regionally instead of going through an inefficient global supply chain. North Dakota pulse crop acreage has grown from 60,000 in 2000 to over 2.5 million acres today.
- While decommoditized markets can offer higher premiums, they also have more stringent requirements around quality, variety, and cleaning.
- High cattle prices make it challenging for ranchers to profit from direct-to-consumer beef sales, as the margins are lower. But it can help insulate them when commodity prices drop.
- The biggest challenge for producers is effective marketing to connect with consumers and tell their story. Advice is to "tell your story from your heart."

The article was based on discussions at the North Dakota Farmers Union's Evolution Ag Summit on February 17, 2026. Experts included Ashley Bruner of Dakota Angus, Wendy Reinhardt Kapsak of the International Food Information Council, and Eric Bartsch of AGT Foods USA.

items.title: Year of the Fire Horse brings speed, momentum and volatility in grain markets
items.description: As China enters the the Year of the Fire Horse, we are in a market that reacts quickly, Allison Thompson says. She provides some strategies for making sure your operation's position is protected.
items.summary:
This 60-year cycle event in Chinese tradition represents intense energy, rapid change, and bold movement, amplifying the Horse's natural traits of independence, speed, and ambition.

Key points:
- Even rumors of China purchasing soybeans can move markets quickly in today's environment.
- Grain markets are reacting sharply to headlines, technical levels, and fund positioning rather than underlying supply and demand fundamentals.
- Sharp rallies fueled by positioning or headlines often fade when export sales or supply changes fail to materialize.
- Volatility can create opportunities, but it does not guarantee structural improvements in the underlying market math.
- With narrow margins, even small 25-cent moves in corn or 40-cent moves in soybeans can have a significant impact on farm balance sheets.
- China's Lunar New Year holiday can amplify short-term price swings due to positioning ahead of expected demand.
- The "Fire Horse" symbolism represents both opportunity and instability - farmers must be disciplined to position for the volatility.
- The goal is not to chase every rally, but to selectively use incremental sales, downside protection, and flexibility to manage risk.

This volatile environment requires preparation and endurance, not just speed and ambition. Farmers must focus on improving their risk profile, not chasing perfection, to build balance sheets in 2026.

items.title: Farm and Dairy Weekly Rundown: Episode 44 (2-19-26)
items.description: Reporters Liz Partsch and Paul Rowley give readers a rundown of the top stories in the Farm and Dairy the week of Feb. 19, 2026. The post Farm and Dairy Weekly Rundown: Episode 44 (2-19-26) appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

1. Pennsylvania will conduct the state's first-ever comprehensive firefly inventory to better understand and protect these insects.
2. "Forever chemicals" like PFAS may be lurking in groundwater and soil across the state, posing a hidden threat to farmers and the environment.
3. The Farm and Dairy Weekly Rundown podcast covers the top agricultural news stories each week, including updates on the Farm Bill and other important issues for farmers.

items.title: Bloom for Good launches ag advocacy savings app
items.description: Bloom for Good launched a savings app that supports 4-H, FFA and Ag in the Classroom through digital membership purchases. The post Bloom for Good launches ag advocacy savings app appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Bloom for Good, a mission-driven company, has launched a new Advocating for Agriculture savings app. The app offers a one-year digital savings membership with discounts at national and local businesses, while directing a portion of purchases back to organizations like 4-H, FFA, and Ag in the Classroom.

Key details:
- Introductory membership price of $15 (regularly $25)
- Mobile app provides discounts on travel, dining, retail, concerts, sporting events, and more
- Proceeds support state and national efforts for agricultural education, including curriculum, leadership development, classroom resources, and hands-on learning
- Aims to address challenges like workforce shortages and declining agricultural literacy by giving supporters a way to contribute

Missy Rosenbusch, Vice President of Agriculture Advocacy & Impact at Bloom for Good, said: "This campaign is about more than savings - it's about advocating with an impact. Every time someone purchases this membership, they are actively standing up for agriculture, education, and youth leadership across America."

The app is intended to be a renewable, year-round campaign to create a dependable funding stream for agricultural education programs nationwide.

items.title: Wildfire preparedness encouraged as conditions remain warm and dry across Texas
items.description: Texas A&M Forest Service offers preparation and preventive tips The post Wildfire preparedness encouraged as conditions remain warm and dry across Texas appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Summary:

- Texas is experiencing warm, dry conditions that increase wildfire risk into early spring 2026. The Texas A&M Forest Service urges all Texans to prepare emergency go-kits and take steps to protect their homes.

- Since January 1, the Forest Service has responded to 249 wildfires that burned 5,528 acres statewide. Wildfire danger is predicted to continue due to drought.

- Recommended preparedness steps include assembling a 5 P emergency kit (people/pet supplies, prescriptions, papers, personal needs, priceless items), creating defensible space around homes, and being cautious with any outdoor activities that could spark a fire.

- Residents should sign up for local emergency alerts, monitor conditions, have evacuation plans, and follow official guidance. Quickly reporting any wildfires can help save lives and property.

- The Forest Service offers information on burn bans, prevention, and the current wildfire situation in Texas.

items.title: North Dakota man taken into custody on charges relating to cattle theft
items.description: A Colfax man is in custody in the Richland County Jail after being charged with two Class A felonies and two Class A misdemeanors relating to the theft and transfer of cattle.
items.summary:
A Colfax, North Dakota man named Daniel Wayne Dockter has been charged with two Class A felonies and two Class A misdemeanors relating to the theft and unlawful transport of cattle. 

The charges stem from two complainants who reported a total of 133 missing head of cows and bulls, with an estimated market value of $460,500. They also reported a total of 103 missing head of calves, with an estimated market value of $309,000. 

The cattle were believed to be under Dockter's care at his property in Colfax. Dockter allegedly failed to make payments to the complainants and provided false information about the location of the cattle. 

Investigations revealed that Dockter did not obtain brand inspection for legal transport of the cattle out of North Dakota. It is believed the cattle were transported from Colfax to South Dakota sometime between January 1, 2024, and January 8, 2026.

Dockter was taken into custody at the Richland County Jail. The case was investigated by Nicholas Marolt, a law enforcement officer employed by the North Dakota Stockmen's Association.

items.title: Trump Directs USDA to Boost Production of Glyphosate
items.description: February 19, 2026 ‚Äì President Donald Trump issued an executive order late Wednesday directing the Secretary of Agriculture to boost the domestic supply of glyphosate, the active ingredient in the herbicide Roundup, in the name of national security. The order emphasizes increasing domestic production of elemental phosphorus, which is created by mining phosphate, to make […] The post Trump Directs USDA to Boost Production of Glyphosate appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The Trump administration has issued an executive order directing the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) to increase domestic production of glyphosate, the active ingredient in the widely used herbicide Roundup. The order, issued on February 19, 2026, cites national security concerns and emphasizes the need to boost domestic production of elemental phosphorus, a key component in glyphosate manufacturing. 

The order aims to reduce the U.S. reliance on imported glyphosate and phosphorus. Currently, the U.S. imports 80% of its phosphorus supply, primarily from China and Morocco. The executive order calls for the USDA to work with the Department of the Interior to expand phosphate mining operations in the U.S. and streamline the permitting process. 

This move is expected to have significant impacts on farmers and the agricultural industry. Increased glyphosate production could lead to lower prices and greater availability of the herbicide, but also raises concerns about potential environmental and health effects. Experts warn that over-reliance on glyphosate-based weed control could contribute to the development of herbicide-resistant weeds, diminishing the effectiveness of this widely used tool.

The order does not provide specific timelines or production targets, but directs the USDA to work with relevant federal agencies to develop a plan to boost domestic glyphosate and phosphorus supplies within 6 months.

items.title: Texas A&M AgriLife Research projects to enhance rice yields, health benefits
items.description: Studies explore new rice breeding technology to improve quality and advance purple rice The post Texas A&M AgriLife Research projects to enhance rice yields, health benefits appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- Texas A&M AgriLife Research is leading two new projects to enhance rice yields, quality, and health benefits.

- The first project, led by Shyamal Talukder, Ph.D., aims to modernize the rice breeding pipeline and improve yield and quality in main and ratoon rice crops. It received over $1.1 million in funding from the USDA.

- The project will use advanced technologies like unmanned aerial systems, genomic selection, and artificial intelligence to shorten the rice breeding cycle and release new varieties faster.

- The second project, also led by Talukder, focuses on enhancing the health benefits of purple rice by increasing nutrient profiles and yields through traditional breeding and multi-omics techniques. It is funded by the USDA Agricultural Research Service.

- The goals are to support U.S. rice producers, maintain the global competitiveness of the U.S. rice industry, and provide consumers with more nutritious rice options.

- The project teams include other Texas A&M AgriLife researchers, Yubin Yang, Ph.D., and Mahendra Bhandari, Ph.D., as well as USDA-ARS researcher Tim Paape, Ph.D.

items.title: Ag commissioner glad to see ICE operations wind down, but concerns remain
items.description: First in the House and then later at the Senate, DFL members from the Twin Cities metro area wanted to hear more of ICE activity on agriculture in Minnesota.
items.summary:
Prior to the recent ICE surge, Minnesota's agriculture sector was already facing labor shortages, especially on farms and in specialty crop farming. Many farms rely on migrant workers who return year after year, operating expensive equipment and managing large operations.

Petersen said farmers have reported having about half the workers they had planned for this spring, as the immigration enforcement activity scared off some of the workers they depend on. While the situation would have been much worse if the ICE surge happened during planting or harvest seasons, it still caused slowdowns in meat processing plants, with some having to cut shifts.

The commissioner expressed relief that the ICE operations are now winding down, but said concerns remain about labor shortages impacting farms, especially during the upcoming growing season and fall harvest. Petersen noted that agriculture's reliance on the H-2A visa program has expanded significantly in recent years across various crop, hog, and dairy operations.

Overall, the ICE crackdown created an immediate disruption in Minnesota's agricultural supply chain and labor force, which Petersen said would have been devastating had it occurred at a more critical time of year for planting and harvesting.

items.title: USDA Ag Outlook Forum Acreage Figures
items.description: USDA this morning released its Agricultural Outlook Forum acreage, yield and production numbers. These are widely anticipated by the trade and will be incorporated into the May WASDE (World Agriculture Supply and Demand Estimates) for corn and soybeans. The May WASDE includes the first official set of supply and demand tables for the new crop year. USDA expects a slight decline in total acreage across wheat, corn, and soybean to 224 million (down ~1%). This number assumes a normal level of preve
items.summary:
Key Highlights:

- USDA released acreage, yield, and production figures for the 2026/27 marketing year at the Agricultural Outlook Forum:
   - Wheat: 45 million acres, 50.8 bushels per acre, 1.86 billion bushels production, $5.00 per bushel price
   - Corn: 94 million acres, 183.0 bushels per acre, 15.76 billion bushels production, $4.20 per bushel price 
   - Soybeans: 85 million acres, 53.0 bushels per acre, 4.45 billion bushels production, $10.30 per bushel price
- Total acreage across wheat, corn, and soybeans is expected to decline slightly by ~1% to 224 million acres.
- The USDA projections will be discussed at the upcoming "All Day Ag Outlook Conference" on March 3, 2026 in Covington, Indiana. 
- The conference will cover topics like weather outlook, grain market fundamentals, competition from South America, farmland outlook, production and budgeting, and expert panel discussions.
- Registration for the conference is $40 per person if purchased by February 27, and $60 thereafter. Media and Extension personnel can register for free.

items.title: USDA announces 2026 CRP enrollment periods
items.description: The sign-up period for landowners to enroll eligible farmland in the Continuous CRP program is Feb. 12 through March 20, 2026.
items.summary:
USDA Announces 2026 CRP Enrollment Periods

The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) has announced the enrollment periods for the Conservation Reserve Program (CRP) at local Farm Service Agency offices:

- Continuous CRP sign-up: February 12 - March 20, 2026
- General CRP sign-up: March 9 - April 17, 2026
- Grassland CRP sign-up: To be announced later by USDA

The CRP is a voluntary program that allows landowners to enroll eligible farmland to promote conservation practices and protect natural resources. 

Key facts:
- CRP was established in 1985 and has been part of every Farm Bill since then.
- As of July 2025, there were 25.8 million acres enrolled in CRP, just below the 27 million acre maximum.
- Of the total CRP acres, 30% are in General CRP, 32% in Continuous CRP, and 38% in Grassland CRP.
- Current CRP contracts on 1.5 million acres will expire on September 30, 2026, with an additional 1.3 million acres expiring in 2027.
- The total annual federal budget for CRP in fiscal year 2024 was $1.9 billion, including $1.79 billion in rental payments to landowners.
- The average CRP rental rate was $72 per acre in 2024, varying by program type.

Experts recommend that farmers and landowners contact their local FSA office or visit the CRP website for details on eligibility, rental rates, and enrollment opportunities in their area.

items.title: Honoring Black Farmers: Our Biggest Stories From the Past 6 Years
items.description: The stories below trace some of the key policy decisions of our recent past and the impact of those decisions on Black farmers. They also explore the new and viable solutions that farmers and farmer advocates have created in the fight for justice. Below are our most important stories about Black farmers from the past […] The post Honoring Black Farmers: Our Biggest Stories From the Past 6 Years appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
2 billion in compensation but many farmers did not receive the full payments owed.
- In 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic disproportionately impacted Black farmers, with 39% reporting financial losses compared to 29% of white farmers.
- The American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 included $4 billion in debt relief for socially disadvantaged farmers, but implementation was delayed by lawsuits.
- Black farmers have seen their farmland ownership decline from 14% in 1910 to just 1.7% today, due to systemic discrimination and USDA policies.
- Organizations like the Federation of Southern Cooperatives and the National Black Farmers Association are working to support and empower Black farmers.
- Experts emphasize the need for sustained policy changes and investment to address the legacy of discrimination and help Black farmers access land, credit, and markets.

items.title: Groundhog Day for the Farm Bill: Why GOP promises keep falling short
items.description: Farm Bill debate is starting to feel like a repeat episode. Alan Guebert dives into why the "modernization" talk doesn't match the math on crop safety nets. The post Groundhog Day for the Farm Bill: Why GOP promises keep falling short appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- The House Agriculture Committee chairman, Republican Glenn "GT" Thompson, has repeatedly promised a new Farm Bill every year since the previous one expired in 2023, but has yet to deliver.

- The GOP-led Congress recently made changes to the farm safety net, increasing spending on farm programs by $65 billion while cutting $186 billion from domestic food assistance programs.

- Economists found that the current farm safety net has more than eliminated crop sector losses since the 2000s, when it was only meant to cover about 1.7% of losses annually.

- The excessive farm subsidies have removed the incentive for efficiency in the market economy, which is a critical failure of the current farm policy.

- Experts recommend debating when and how to curtail or eliminate crop safety net payments when market returns are positive, including crop insurance subsidies.

- Given the political divisions in Congress, it is unlikely the House will be able to pass a new Farm Bill before the 2026 elections.

items.title: The ‘Wimpy’ Problem: How to properly value sweat equity on the farm
items.description: Don't wait until "Tuesday" to pay for today‚Äôs labor. OSU's Dave Marrison talk about how to document farm sweat equity, calculate opportunity costs, and ensure a fair family transition. The post The ‘Wimpy’ Problem: How to properly value sweat equity on the farm appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Sweat equity is a common issue for farm families, where the successor generation is underpaid compared to their market value, with a promise to "make it up later" that often doesn't materialize.

- Example: Johnny Holstein could earn $65,000 as an assistant herdsman, but is paid $50,000 on his parents' 55-cow dairy, a $15,000 annual opportunity cost that totals $225,000 over 15 years.

- To address this, families should document sweat equity contributions in the transition plan, and consider distributing the first $225,000 of the estate to Johnny before dividing the rest.

- Compensation should be tracked transparently, including wages, benefits, housing, food, vehicles, etc. for each family member.

- Sweat equity can also arise from the heir's contribution to farm growth; families should discuss how to attribute that value.

- Non-business contributions like caregiving should also be factored into sweat equity.

- OSU Extension offers "Planning for the Future of Your Farm" workshops to help families navigate these complex transition issues.

items.title: Sunburns and short Sleeves: Surviving the Northern Plains’ false spring
items.description: Eliza Blue reflects on the sensory magic and "false hope" of a South Dakota January thaw, from spotting early robins to the sting of a surprise winter sunburn. The post Sunburns and short Sleeves: Surviving the Northern Plains’ false spring appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
This year's false spring has been particularly long-lasting, starting in January and continuing into February.

The author, Eliza Blue, a shepherd and writer in western South Dakota, describes the physical sensations and visual cues that make it feel like spring, such as robins and geese returning, and her daughter wanting to wear summer clothes. However, Blue cautions that this is not true spring, and the warm weather can lead to issues like sunburns.

The article provides the following key details:

- This year's false spring started in January and continued into February, with people wearing t-shirts on Valentine's Day.
- Blue heard a flock of robins and saw a flock of geese, signs that typically indicate the arrival of spring.
- Blue's daughter was excited to pull out next summer's clothes, but Blue made her come back inside to avoid sunburn.
- Blue herself got a sunburn on her chin from the unexpected warmth.
- The false spring is expected to end soon, with the author only having a fading tan and peeling chin as evidence of the brief warm period.

The article highlights the disconnect between the physical sensations of warmth and the reality that true spring has not yet arrived. It serves as a cautionary tale for farmers and residents of the Northern Plains about the risks of false spring, such as sunburns and being caught off-guard by the return of winter weather.

items.title: Texas dairy producers offset lower milk prices with higher calf prices
items.description: Texas Crop and Weather Report - Feb. 18, 2026 The post Texas dairy producers offset lower milk prices with higher calf prices appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Beef-on-dairy calf prices have risen from $600 per calf in 2024 to as high as $1,500 per calf currently. This helps offset the decline in milk prices, which dropped from $20.55 per hundredweight in December 2024 to $16.93 per hundredweight in December 2025. Cheese and butter prices also declined over this period.

Texas milk production increased from 17 billion pounds in 2024 to 18.2 billion pounds in 2025, driven by more dairy cows (675,000 to 705,000 head) and improved genetics, nutrition and cow comfort. However, expansion is expected to slow from 7.6% per year from 2016-2021 to 7% from 2024-2025, due to growth in other states like western Kansas and ongoing water challenges in the Texas Panhandle.

The article provides regional weather and crop updates across Texas. Key points include beneficial rainfall in some areas providing relief, while drought conditions persisted in others. Wheat and pasture conditions were mixed, requiring supplemental feeding for livestock in many regions. Preparation for spring planting was underway.

Overall, the Texas dairy industry is adapting to lower milk prices by leveraging higher calf prices, but expansion is expected to slow due to regional factors. Farmers across the state faced varied weather and crop conditions requiring ongoing management.

items.title: Proposed USDA Rules Would Increase Line Speeds at Meatpacking Plants
items.description: February 18, 2026 ‚Äì The U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) announced proposed rules Tuesday that would speed up line speeds at poultry and pork production facilities. Under the proposals, maximum chicken slaughter line speeds could increase from 140 birds per minute (bpm) to 175. It would also allow turkey processing lines to increase from 55 […] The post Proposed USDA Rules Would Increase Line Speeds at Meatpacking Plants appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The USDA has proposed new rules that would increase maximum slaughter line speeds at poultry and pork production facilities. The key details are:

- Maximum chicken slaughter line speeds could increase from 140 birds per minute (bpm) to 175 bpm.
- Turkey processing lines could increase from 55 bpm to an unspecified higher speed.
- Pork processing line speeds could also be increased, but the proposed new maximum was not provided.
- These rule changes are aimed at increasing production at meatpacking plants.
- The proposals were announced on February 18, 2026 by the USDA.
- Critics argue the higher line speeds will compromise worker safety and animal welfare. 
- Farmers and industry groups have not yet publicly responded to the proposed changes.
- The USDA is seeking public comments on the proposals before finalizing any new rules.

items.title: Sensory science researcher unlocks what drives perceived flavors
items.description: Pellegrino joins the Department of Animal Science to study flavor, behavior and consumer decision-making The post Sensory science researcher unlocks what drives perceived flavors appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Robert Pellegrino, Ph.D., has joined the Texas A&M Department of Animal Science as an assistant professor of sensory science, starting in February 2026.

- His research focuses on understanding the chemical, structural, and temporal features of sensory stimuli that contribute to perceived flavor, and how odor, taste, and texture interact to shape eating experiences and influence consumer decision-making.

- Pellegrino has been at the forefront of digitizing odors, creating models to predict odor intensity and quality, and developing a universal odor scale and a process to digitally recreate odors.

- He has also contributed to projects focused on improving eating experiences for individuals who have lost their sense of smell, including developing a cookbook and exploring how other cues can enhance food enjoyment.

- Pellegrino will teach ANSC 487: Sensory Evaluation of Foods starting in spring 2027, focusing on introducing students to sensory evaluation methods and their applications.

- Beyond Texas A&M, Pellegrino is active in the global sensory science community, serving in leadership roles with the Global Consortium for Chemosensory Research and the International Society of Neurogastronomy.

items.title: FDA Finalizes Controversial Guidelines for Livestock Antibiotics
items.description: February 17, 2026 ‚Äì Officials at the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) published a final guidance document on Friday that advises drug companies to set ‚Äúduration limits‚Äù for livestock antibiotics in animal feed, without legally obligating them to do so. The duration limit‚Äîthe maximum length of time a drug should be given‚Äîcovers medically important antibiotics, […] The post FDA Finalizes Controversial Guidelines for Livestock Antibiotics appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The FDA has finalized guidelines for the use of livestock antibiotics, advising drug companies to set "duration limits" on the length of time medically important antibiotics can be used in animal feed. However, these limits are not legally binding. The guidelines aim to curb the overuse of antibiotics in livestock, which contributes to the rise of antibiotic-resistant bacteria. While some experts applaud the effort, others argue the guidelines do not go far enough to address the issue. The guidelines do not provide specific duration limits, leaving it up to drug companies to determine appropriate timeframes. Farmers and consumer advocates are concerned that without enforceable restrictions, the overuse of antibiotics in livestock will continue. The guidelines come amidst growing public health concerns over the threat of antibiotic resistance, which the CDC estimates causes over 35,000 deaths annually in the United States.

items.title: How Dealers Should Answer the ‚ÄúMost Reliable Tractor‚Äù Question
items.description: Every dealer hears it:‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the most reliable tractor you sell?‚Äù It sounds like a product question. It‚Äôs actually a trust question. Farmers aren‚Äôt asking you to crown a winner. They‚Äôre asking whether this decision will cost them time, money, or sleep when it matters most. Dealers who lead with a brand name risk missing the […] The post How Dealers Should Answer the ‚ÄúMost Reliable Tractor‚Äù Question appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
It emphasizes that this is not a simple product question, but rather a question of trust - farmers want to know if the tractor decision will cost them time, money, or sleep when it matters most.

The key points are:

1. Reframe reliability as "uptime" rather than just a brand name. Guide the buyer with questions about service, response times, and parts availability.

2. Clarify the farmer's ownership strategy - is this a long-term workhorse or a short-term asset? Recommend accordingly.

3. Use auction data to show real-world resale performance, which reflects serviceability and familiarity more than marketing.

4. Be transparent about current market conditions and timing, as that also impacts reliability.

The article recommends a "Dealer Reliability Framework" focused on service/uptime, ownership timeline, market conditions, and real-world resale data - rather than just promoting a brand name. Dealers who provide this intelligence can build trust and help farmers make confident decisions.

Experts quoted include Casey Seymour of Farm Journal and Greg Peterson (Machinery Pete), who emphasize that trust and data are the most reliable assets for dealers today.

items.title: Is sulfur a mobile nutrient? Carryover, soybean needs, and S fertilizer product differences
items.summary:
Key Findings:
- Sulfur can carry over in Minnesota soils for at least 2 years, covering corn's sulfur needs during that time. Applying 10 lbs of sulfate per acre for 4 years resulted in carryover.
- Soybeans do need sulfur to grow, but direct sulfur application only benefited soybean yield in 2 out of 30 trials. Sulfur applied ahead of corn in a corn-soybean rotation was enough to benefit both crops.
- For sulfur-bentonite products like Tiger-Sul, immediate incorporation results in poor sulfur availability. It takes 5-6 years for the same sulfur rate to be as effective as an annual sulfate application.
- Sources like MicroEssentials or MST have greater sulfur availability than sulfur-bentonite products.

Statistics/Numbers:
- 4-year study with annual sulfur rates of 5, 10, and 20 lbs/acre, comparing sulfate to elemental sulfur.
- 2 out of 30 soybean trials showed a yield benefit from direct sulfur application.
- 2-year corn-soybean rotation trials showed 20 lbs/acre of sulfur, regardless of source, benefited both crops.
- Tiger-90 took 5-6 years to match annual sulfate application effectiveness.

Dates/Deadlines:
- 8-year study ending in 2026 growing season.

Organizations:
- Agricultural Fertilizer Research and Education Council (AFREC)
- Minnesota Soybean Research and Promotion Council

Locations:
- Rosemount and Waseca, Minnesota

Recommendations/Actions:
- Apply sulfur to high-demand crops like corn, alfalfa, and canola.
- For sulfur-bentonite products, do not incorporate for at least 2 weeks after application or apply an additional sulfate/thiosulfate source in the spring.
- Sources like MicroEssentials or MST have greater sulfur availability.

Expert Quote:
"While it is true that sulfate has a negative charge and can be leached, the rate of leaching really depends on the soil."
- Daniel Kaiser, Extension Nutrient Management Specialist

items.title: MN CropCast: Unlocking the soybean genome with Dr. Bob Stupar
items.summary:
Key points:

- The article discusses an interview with Dr. Bob Stupar, Professor of Agronomy and Plant Genetics and Legume Geneticist at the University of Minnesota.

- Dr. Stupar discussed his work in unlocking the soybean genome and using gene editing to improve soybean quality traits like reducing antinutritional components.

- He emphasized the importance of maintaining and updating reference genomes, which are essential "blueprints" for scientific advancement.

- Dr. Stupar shared that his proudest contribution is graduate student training and workforce development, ensuring the next generation of scientists is ready to lead.

- The interview was part of the Minnesota CropCast podcast, hosted by David Nicolai and Seth Naeve, which discusses progress and challenges in Minnesota's agronomic crops.

- The podcast episode was recorded on February 18, 2026.

items.title: Confusion and ‚ÄòMore Chaos‚Äô as States Implement SNAP Food Restrictions
items.description: Since 2018, the entrepreneurial couple has benefited from the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), which they‚Äôve used to support themselves and their children, and to keep the business running. As small business owners who strive to offer good-paying jobs to their employees and give back to the community as much as possible, they don’t have […] The post Confusion and ‚ÄòMore Chaos‚Äô as States Implement SNAP Food Restrictions appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Since 2018, an entrepreneurial couple has relied on SNAP benefits to support their family and business. As small business owners, they strive to provide good-paying jobs and give back to their community.

In 2021, 13 states implemented new SNAP restrictions, including banning the use of SNAP benefits to purchase hot foods and prepared meals. This has created confusion among SNAP recipients, who are unsure of what they can and cannot buy. Some small businesses that previously accepted SNAP payments have had to stop, leading to "more chaos" for their customers.

The new SNAP restrictions aim to limit the use of benefits for less healthy food options. However, this is causing hardship for low-income families and small businesses that rely on SNAP transactions. There are concerns that these changes will make it more difficult for SNAP recipients to access affordable, nutritious food.

Experts emphasize the need for clear, consistent communication from state agencies to help SNAP recipients understand the new rules. Small business owners also call for more flexibility and support to continue serving their SNAP-reliant customers.

items.title: Improving waterhemp control by managing spray water pH
items.summary:
The key points from the article are:

- A 2025 field study in Rochester, Minnesota evaluated how spray water pH adjustment and timing of spray solution mixing affected waterhemp control in a corn herbicide program.

- All treatments included a tank mix of atrazine and Acuron GT (applied at full or half rate) with NIS and AMS. Treatments differed by presence/absence of a pH-lowering adjuvant (AlpHa Shot) and timing of spray solution mixing (6 days prior or at time of spraying).

- Adding the pH-lowering adjuvant reduced spray water pH from 7.5 to 5.8, improving waterhemp control by 10% at 24 days after treatment (DAT) and 7% at 112 DAT.

- Waterhemp density decreased by 64% and biomass reduced by 55% with the pH-adjusting adjuvant, resulting in lower late-season weed pressure and seed production.

- Timing of mixing the pH adjuster (6 days ahead or at spraying) did not affect waterhemp control, density or biomass.

- The response to pH adjustment was seen at both full and half rates of Acuron GT, indicating water quality can influence herbicide performance regardless of rate.

- Adjusting and buffering spray water pH is a simple step that can protect herbicide performance and improve season-long weed management when water makes up most of the spray tank.

items.title: 5 Cover Crops You Can Plant in February
items.description: Most farmers plant cover crops in the fall, and let the winter terminate them before they go to seed. But you can still plant cover crops in winter, as long as you know which will work in your climate. Plant these five cover crops this month for early spring benefits. The post 5 Cover Crops You Can Plant in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Consider these 5 cover crop options:

- Spinach - An easy cold-weather ground cover that can increase good soil bacteria and fungi. Especially beneficial for later pepper crops. Needs soil temp of at least 40¬∞F to germinate.

- Kale - A multipurpose cover crop that feeds the soil, you, customers, and livestock. Kale needs slightly warmer soil of 45¬∞F. Opt for disease-resistant varieties if issues are common.  

- Daikon radish - Also called forage radish, the deep taproots can break up compacted soil and scavenge leftover nitrogen. Requires soil of at least 65¬∞F to sow.

- Oats - Grow quickly to cover soil and prevent weed germination. Form beneficial relationships with fungi. Sow at 4-6 oz per 100 sq ft, can terminate without harvesting.

- Buckwheat - A quick-growing "phosphorus scavenger" that conditions poor soils. Attracts pollinators and can be used as an organic mulch.

Planting cover crops in February offers benefits like improved soil health, carbon sequestration, erosion prevention, and potential yield increases for subsequent cash crops. Farmers should consider their local climate and soil conditions when selecting the best options.

items.title: Strategic Farming: Let's talk crops! session talked forecasting tools for crop and pest management
items.summary:
Topics covered included:

- Overwintering insect pests: Insects use strategies like producing antifreeze compounds to survive cold Minnesota winters. Temperatures below -29¬∞F can kill 50-95% of soybean aphid eggs, while soil temps below 10¬∞F can reduce corn rootworm egg survival by 60%.

- Forecasting migratory pests: Pheromone traps and degree day models are used to predict the arrival and development of pests like black cutworm, potato leafhopper, and corn earworm that migrate northward each season.

- Crop disease forecasting: The IPM PIPE website maps the spread of diseases like southern rust and tar spot of corn to alert farmers. The Minnesota Ag Weather Network provides data on weather conditions that influence disease risk.

- Pest and disease degree day models: The North Dakota Ag Weather Network (NDAWN) hosts numerous degree day calculators to time management practices for pests and diseases in crops like corn, wheat, sugarbeets, and canola.

- Expert recommendations: Scouting fields is still essential to verify predictions from forecasting tools. Farmers should consult resources like the Fusarium Head Blight risk tool and leaf rust models to manage diseases in small grains.

The webinar series runs through March 2026, and recordings are available online. The expanding Minnesota Ag Weather Network aims to provide more localized data to support these forecasting tools for farmers.

items.title: Freeze, Thaw, Seed: Timing Pasture Renovation in an Unpredictable Winter
items.description: This winter‚Äôs erratic weather, swinging from ‚Äì30¬∞F wind chills to unseasonably warm temperatures in the 50s, has left many wanting spring and ready to get back in the fields. Even though the groundhog predicted six more weeks of winter, temperatures have been trending upward. Over the next week, highs are expected to stay above freezing during the day and drop below freezing at night. These natural freeze‚Äìthaw cycles signal the slow transition into spring.
items.summary:
Frost seeding involves broadcasting or overseeding legumes into a thinning pasture or small grain stand, with the freeze-thaw cycle working the seed into the soil and improving seed-to-soil contact. 

The article notes that over the next week, daytime highs are expected to stay above freezing while nighttime lows drop below freezing, creating ideal conditions for frost seeding. However, success depends heavily on timing, soil conditions, and the condition of the existing stand. 

Farmers are encouraged to review the "Frosting Seeding Legumes" article in the Encyclopedia for more information on best practices. The article was written by Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist at Iowa State University who joined the Department of Agronomy in November 2023. Her research focuses on optimizing forage-based systems through strategies to enhance resilience and productivity.

items.title: Frosting Seeding Legumes
items.description: Frost seeding involves strategically broadcasting or overseeding legumes, such as red clover, into a tired pasture or within a small grain stand. It is a potentially cost-effective solution to revitalize a diminishing stand or introduce legumes to an existing forage stand. Frost seeding is usually not recommended with grass species. The success of frost seeding hinges upon assessing the condition of the existing stand and seeding at the proper time.
items.summary:
This can be a cost-effective way to revitalize a diminishing stand or introduce legumes.

Timing is critical - frost seeding is typically done between mid-February and early March to coincide with the freeze-thaw cycle, which helps incorporate the seed into the soil. Seed should be applied to bare soil, not snow-covered ground.

The condition of the existing stand is also important. A thick thatch can hinder seed-to-soil contact, so it's recommended to closely graze or hay the area in the fall/winter before seeding. Bare spots are a good indicator that frost seeding may work well.

Soil type matters - frost seeding tends to be more successful on loam or clay soils that expand/contract during freeze-thaw, rather than sandy soils. Avoiding soil compaction by seeding when the ground is frozen is also important.

Adequate spring moisture is vital for establishing a healthy frost-seeded stand. While the potential benefits are high, timing, soil conditions, and moisture all play crucial roles in the success of frost seeding.

The article was authored by Dr. Shelby Gruss, an assistant professor and forage extension specialist at Iowa State University who joined the department in November 2023. Her research focuses on optimizing forage-based systems.

items.title: 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February
items.description: It takes a lot to get the farm ready for the growing season. It all begins with the task of gathering together and starting vegetable seeds. February is an ideal time to get many of your spring crops going. Consider these 7 vegetables as you prepare your rows. The post 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Here are the key points:

1. February is a good time to start seeds indoors, using protected environments like greenhouses, cold frames, or low/high tunnels. This gives plants a head start before the outdoor growing season.

2. Slow-growing herbs like basil, oregano, and rosemary should be started in February, as they can take 1-4 weeks to germinate.

3. Tomatoes should be started in February, especially for growers in warmer regions. They take at least 80 days from seed to fruit.

4. Peppers are notoriously slow to germinate, taking up to a month. They also need 2-3 months to mature. Productive varieties include jalape√±os, serranos, and shishitos.

5. Brassicas like broccoli, cabbage, kale, and cauliflower thrive in the cool spring weather. Leafy types grow quickly, while heading types take longer and may need winter protection.

6. Lettuce is easy to grow from seed in February and can handle light frosts. Leaf lettuces grow quickly, while heading types take more time.

7. Carrots and parsnips should be directly sown outdoors in February, as their taproots don't like being disturbed.

8. Onions and leeks should be planted from seed in February, as they take 75-140 days to mature.

The article emphasizes the importance of using protected growing environments like greenhouses, cold frames, and tunnels to get a head start on the growing season, even in cold climates.

items.title: Feb 06 | Weather Update and Market Review

The cold end to January pushed the month as a whole to be around 2 degrees below normal statewide.…

- Precipitation was scarce, with most areas receiving less than 0.1 inches of light snow. January ended around 2 inches drier than normal statewide.
- The heavy snowfall in southern IL (e.g. 20 inches in Du Quoin) had low water content, providing little drought relief. Soils remain very dry and streams are low.
- Temperatures are expected to warm up to the 40s-50s next week, but precipitation will remain light at under 0.1 inches.
- Experts John Jones, Gary Schnitkey, and Laura Gentry recommend using the N-Rate Calculator and Precision Conservation Management program to maximize profits rather than just yields, balancing nitrogen applications to protect watersheds.
- WILLAg.org radio programs "Commodity Week" and "Closing Market Report" discuss agricultural market updates.

items.title: Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers
items.description: For many years, click-through rate was the primary metric used to judge digital performance in agriculture. Today, it no longer tells the full story. Farmers are searching differently, using AI-assisted tools, voice search and quick-scan platforms that often answer their questions without the need to click at all. With this shift, the true indicator of […] The post Why Attention Matters More Than Response for Advertisers appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary: Farmers are now using more AI-assisted tools, voice search, and quick-scan platforms that often provide answers without needing to click. As a result, attention has become a more important metric than response rates for advertisers. Experts recommend that agricultural advertisers focus more on capturing farmer attention through engaging content, rather than just measuring clicks.

items.title: Evaluating soybean performance in conservation systems – project report
items.description: You can also read the article in Portuguese and Spanish Introduction Recent dust storm events in central Illinois and across the Midwest have renewed attention on soil conservation, especially after the tragic May 2023 event near Springfield that caused an 80-vehicle pileup, eight fatalities, and dozens of injuries. These incidents highlight that soil loss is not only an agronomic issue but also a public safety and environmental concern. Reduced tillage and cover crops are well-established pract
items.summary:
Summarizing the key points from the agricultural news article:

The article reports on a 2-year project evaluating soybean performance in conservation agricultural systems in central Illinois and north-central Iowa. The study compared 4 management systems - conventional tillage (CT), fall strip-tillage (ST), no-tillage (NT), and no-tillage with a cereal rye cover crop (NT+CR) - each with 3 starter fertilizer strategies (unfertilized control, 15 lb N/ac, and 15 lb N/ac + 10 lb S/ac).

Key findings:
- Starter fertilizer increased early-season soybean biomass by 12% on average, but these early differences did not persist to later growth stages.
- Soybean yields ranged from 60-95 bu/ac across the 6 locations and 2 years, with no significant yield differences between tillage/cover crop systems.
- When accounting for operational costs, no-till had the highest partial net return, followed by strip-till and conventional tillage. No-till with cereal rye had the lowest partial net return due to higher cover crop management costs.

The project will continue in 2026 to track medium-term responses as the soil and residue dynamics change under the conservation systems. More data will be released once the trial is completed.

items.title: The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now
items.description: When winter is halfway over, growing out of the elements is the only option for many farmers. Here, we share how to use a greenhouse to grow what the climate doesn‚Äôt allow and keep the revenue flowing. The post The February Greenhouse: What to Grow Now appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Greenhouses provide an enclosure that traps thermal heat, allowing for growing even when it's cold outside. 

Modular plastic greenhouses can raise temperatures up to 30 degrees higher, but require ventilation. Low tunnels and cold frames are simpler options that can raise temperatures 2-15 degrees. Larger, fortified greenhouses with climate controls allow for year-round growing.

Key crops to grow in February greenhouses include:
- Tomatoes and peppers, which benefit from the early start and consistent warmth and moisture
- Brassicas like kale, cabbage, cauliflower, and broccoli rabe, which can be protected from pests
- Lettuces, which can be grown earlier for spring markets
- Potatoes, to get a head start on full-sized or baby potatoes
- Onions, including sets, seeds, and bunching onions
- Flowers like lisianthus, coneflowers, and dahlias that take a long time to sprout

The article notes the importance of understanding the specific capabilities of your greenhouse setup to choose the best crops to grow. It advises using seed trays, heating mats, automatic lighting, and proper ventilation and climate control as needed.

The inaugural event is set for Nov. 18-20, 2026, at the Hilton San Diego Bayfront. The article may be republished without further permission if published as written and if credit is given to the author, Integrated Crop Management News, and Iowa State University Extension and Outreach.

items.title: Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer.
items.description: Lead generation starts with delivering real value in exchange for a farmer‚Äôs time and attention. The CTA and offer you choose shape not only how many leads you capture, but how qualified, motivated and purchase-ready those prospects become. When you shift your mindset from what you want to collect to what farmers genuinely need in […] The post Stop Chasing Leads. Start Designing the Right Offer. appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Lead generation should focus on delivering real value in exchange for farmers' time and attention, not just collecting leads.
- The call-to-action (CTA) and offer you choose shape both the quantity and quality of leads captured - more qualified, motivated, and purchase-ready prospects.
- Shift your mindset from what you want to collect to what farmers genuinely need, rather than chasing leads.
- Designing the right offer is critical to capturing high-quality leads that are more likely to convert into customers.

The article does not provide any specific numbers, dates, names, locations, or expert quotes. It discusses the general concept of lead generation and offers for agricultural marketing, without citing data or details from the original source.
