However, a strong winter storm is forecast to bring significant snowfall, especially to southern Illinois, with 8-12 inches expected south of Interstate 64.

The article also mentions the latest episode of the Commodity Week radio program, which featured panelists Chip Nellinger of Blue Reef Agri-Marketing, Brian Stark from The Andersons, and Arlan Suderman with StoneX. The Closing Market Report is also aired daily on WILL AM580.

items.title: Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing
items.description: The world is searching for information a bit differently these days. Gone are the days of winning the click (traditional SEO). The game now is centered on winning brand authority and trust (modern AEO, answer engine optimization). In a world now crowded with ‚ÄúAI slop,‚Äù brands will only cut through by growing brand authority and […] The post Brand and Content Discoverability Is the New Battleground in Ag Marketing appeared first on Farm Journal.
items.summary:
The main finding is that the focus in agricultural marketing is shifting from traditional search engine optimization (SEO) to building brand authority and trust through "answer engine optimization" (AEO). Brands now need to focus on content discoverability and providing accurate, helpful information to cut through the noise of "AI slop" in a crowded online space.

There are no specific numbers, prices, statistics, or percentages mentioned. The article does not provide any dates, deadlines, or names of people/organizations/programs.

The article discusses this shift in the agricultural marketing landscape, noting that the days of "winning the click" through traditional SEO are over. The new focus is on establishing brand authority and trust by optimizing content for answer engines, which prioritize providing the most relevant and helpful information to users.

The impact for farmers is that they need to re-evaluate their marketing strategies to prioritize building brand credibility and discoverability, rather than just trying to rank highly in search engine results. Recommendations or action items are not explicitly stated, but the implication is that farmers and agricultural businesses need to focus on creating high-quality, informative content that directly addresses their audience's needs and questions.

No expert quotes are provided in the article.

items.title: Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land
items.description: Also called agroforestry, forest farming is a great way to work within your environmental parameters and utilize the tree canopy to produce more for your farm. Especially for those who live in forested areas, this practice enhances farm output without compromising the ecosystem. The post Forest Farming: Why it Might Make Sense for Your Land appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Originating in Brazil's tropical rainforests, this farming method takes advantage of the high productivity and biodiversity of forested areas.

The article outlines the benefits of forest farming, including:
- Improved water and soil quality, with tree roots holding more water and recharging groundwater.
- Carbon storage, with trees able to store up to 22 lbs of carbon per year in the first 20 years.
- Supporting diverse ecosystems of beneficial insects, birds, mammals, and fungi.
- Ability to grow specialty crops like mushrooms, ramps, syrups, and edible roots that thrive in forested environments.

The article advises that existing forested or riparian areas on a farm are ideal for implementing an agroforestry system. It recommends consulting local agricultural extension offices to develop a forest management plan and understand market opportunities for forest-grown crops.

Considerations include managing invasive tree species, understanding regulations around wild plant harvesting, and exploring various sales channels like online, agritourism, and direct-to-consumer options. The article emphasizes that forest farming does not need to be a large-scale operation and can benefit even small farms with some forested land.

Overall, the article presents forest farming as an ecological and economically viable option for farmers looking to diversify their operations and integrate their land into the surrounding landscape.

items.title: Getting Started with Spray Drones in Iowa: A Practical Guide
items.description: Spray drones are increasingly being evaluated by Iowa farmers as an additional tool for crop input application. When used appropriately, these systems can provide flexibility for timely applications, reduce fi
items.summary:
When used appropriately, spray drones can provide flexibility for timely applications, reduce field traffic, and improve access to difficult areas. However, adopting this technology requires careful consideration of regulations, training, insurance, and management practices.

Key details:
- Spray drones can be useful for applications when soils are too wet, applying to tall crops, reducing compaction, and targeted/site-specific applications.
- Regulatory requirements include FAA Part 107 Remote Pilot Certificate, FAA Part 137 Certification for aerial pesticide application, and Iowa Department of Agriculture and Land Stewardship (IDALS) licensing.
- Specialized insurance coverage is needed, including chemical liability, general liability, and hull/physical damage.
- Equipment selection factors include spray tank capacity, battery life, nozzle options, and GPS guidance features.
- Proper training is essential for safe and effective operation, including flight experience, calibration, weather monitoring, and maintenance.
- Farmers are encouraged to start on a limited scale, compare to conventional methods, and develop efficient procedures.
- Educational resources are available from Iowa State University, IDALS, and equipment dealers.
- Ongoing advancements in payload, automation, and integration with precision ag are expected.

The article provides a comprehensive guide for Iowa farmers to evaluate and adopt spray drone technology responsibly and effectively.

items.title: The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow
items.description: For farms in colder areas, starting seeds in time for the spring market requires a significant amount of time and indoor space. Winter sowing is a method that can be done outdoors and gives seedlings a stronger constitution as they mature. Here, we share plants that thrive when winter sown. The post The 9 Best Flowers and Vegetables to Winter Sow appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
It involves sowing seeds in reused containers like milk jugs or plastic bags and placing them outdoors to benefit from cold, moist winter conditions.

The best vegetables for winter sowing include hardy greens like kale, cabbage, and spinach. Cabbages come in standard and specialty varieties like Napa and 'Carex' with shorter maturation. Spinach varieties like 'Avon' and 'Space' resist mildew and bolting. Onions, especially long-day, short-day, and intermediate-day types, also do well when winter sown. Other great options are leafy greens like kale, collards, chard, and microgreens.

For flowers, perennials that need cold stratification are ideal, such as pansies, echinacea, snapdragons, larkspur, and scabiosa. Pansies provide early spring blooms, while echinacea, snapdragons, larkspur, and scabiosa attract beneficial insects.

The article emphasizes that winter sowing allows growers to maximize spring profits and productivity by getting a head start on hardy crops. It provides all the benefits of direct sowing with less risk to sensitive seedlings.

items.title: 2026 Crop Advantage Series Meetings to Be Held at 12 Locations in January
items.description: AMES, Iowa ‚Äì The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will take place at 12 locations across the state Jan. 6‚Äì29. Each meeting will feature tailored topics selected based on local growing conditions and challenges, presented by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach specialists.
items.summary:
The 2026 Crop Advantage Series will be held at 12 locations across Iowa from January 6 to January 29. The meetings, organized by Iowa State University Extension and Outreach, will provide farmers and crop production professionals with the latest research-based information to help them make informed decisions for the upcoming growing season.

Key details:
- Dates and locations: January 6 - Sioux Center, January 7 - Storm Lake, January 8 - Burlington, January 9 - Mason City, January 13 - Estherville, January 15 - Waterloo, January 16 - Davenport, January 21 - Ankeny, January 22 - Atlantic, January 27 - Iowa City, January 28 - Le Mars, January 29 - Carroll
- Early-bird registration is $75 until the week before each meeting, and late or on-site registration is $100
- Registration includes refreshments, lunch, certified crop advisor credits, and access to resources
- Private pesticide applicator recertification will be available for a separate fee of $30
- Topics will include crop market and climate outlooks, nitrates and drinking water, profitable nutrient management, southern rust, transition planning, and robots/drones
- The goal is to help producers manage potential issues by sharing the latest scientific knowledge from Iowa State University researchers

According to Josh Michel, field agronomist with ISU Extension and Outreach, "Our goal is always to prepare producers to manage potential issues when they arise, or even before they arise, by sharing the most up-to-date scientific knowledge from Iowa State University researchers."

items.title: Purdue field day to feature research on sorghum‚Äôs value as a forage crop
items.description: Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on Sept. 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center (FPAC) in Bedford, Indiana.
items.summary:
Purdue University Extension will host a Forage Sorghum Field Day on September 10 at the Feldun-Purdue Ag Center in Bedford, Indiana. Interested participants should register by September 5.

The event will feature research on sorghum's value as a forage crop, highlighting its drought tolerance, lower nitrogen requirements, and lack of relationship with the tar spot pathogen, compared to corn. Agronomy experts, including Mitch Tuinstra, will share plant breeding techniques to improve sorghum yield and quality.

Other speakers include Brad Shelton (FPAC superintendent), Jason Tower (Southern Indiana Purdue Agricultural Center superintendent), Nick Minton (Purdue Extension beef systems specialist), and Jeff Jackson (Croplan alfalfa and forage specialist). Venue tours will be available from 3-5 p.m. and 6-8 p.m., and a dinner and bull test station tour will be offered from 5-6 p.m.

The field day aims to provide farmers with information on the production and utilization of forage sorghum for silage, grazing, and as a standing winter feed source.

items.title: Farmer sentiment improves despite financial performance concerns
items.description: Three broad-based measures of farmer sentiment improved in July as the Purdue University/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rose 8 points to 113, the Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations at 119 was 7 points higher than a month earlier. Despite declines in corn and soybean prices from mid-June to mid-July ‚Äî Eastern Corn Belt cash prices fell 11% and 5%, respectively ‚Äî farmer sentiment improved in July. Responses to the individual questi
items.summary:
Key points:

- Farmer sentiment improved in July 2024, with the Purdue/CME Group Ag Economy Barometer index rising 8 points to 113.

- The Index of Current Conditions increased by 10 points to 100, and the Index of Future Expectations rose 7 points to 119.

- Despite declines in corn and soybean prices (11% and 5% respectively), sentiment improved due to fewer respondents reporting worsened conditions and lower expectations of negative future outcomes.

- The top concerns for farmers were high input costs (34%), risk of lower crop/livestock prices (29%), and rising interest rates (17%, down from 23% in June).

- The Farm Financial Performance Index dropped 4 points to 81, 6 points lower than July 2023, reflecting worries about weakening commodity prices and high input costs.

- The Farm Capital Investment Index rose 6 points to 38, though it remains 7 points lower than July 2023, as fewer producers believe it's a bad time to make large investments.

- The Short-Term Farmland Value Expectations Index rose to 118, while the Long-Term Index dropped 6 points to 146, with fewer farmers expecting values to rise over the next five years.

- 72% of crop farmers expect cash rental rates to remain roughly the same as 2024, with 15% anticipating an increase and 13% expecting a decrease.

items.title: Purdue researchers adopt interdisciplinary approach to assessing emerging tar spot disease in corn
items.description: For more than a century, tar spot fungal disease in corn kept its distance from the U.S., biding its time
items.summary:
Purdue researchers are taking an interdisciplinary approach to assess the emerging tar spot disease in corn:

- Tar spot, a fungal disease, was first detected in the U.S. in 2015 and has since spread to 16 states and Ontario, Canada. It has also affected crops in 15 other countries.

- The research team, led by C.D. Cruz, associate professor of botany and plant pathology at Purdue, is using a mix of statistical, data science, epidemiology, microbiology, artificial intelligence, and computer vision methods to better understand the dynamics of tar spot.

- The work is funded by two USDA grants totaling nearly $1.1 million. Collaborators include researchers from Colombia, Mexico, Ecuador, South Korea, and the U.S.

- Previous efforts include developing a digital method for quantifying tar spot using an algorithm called SCDA, which was tested against human raters. Ongoing work aims to improve the model's accuracy.

- Another research effort involves a collaboration between the agricultural and engineering teams, led by Mohammad Jahanshahi, to adapt computer vision and AI approaches from civil infrastructure monitoring to detect and classify crop disease symptoms.

- The team is also working on quantifying and modeling tar spot epidemics in production-style fields, using disease observations and drone-based imagery.

- The interdisciplinary approach aims to provide rapid and accurate information to stakeholders, addressing the urgent need to address biosecurity challenges with a science-based approach.

items.title: ISA will host sheep-themed educational opportunities and competitions at Indiana State Fair
items.description: In addition to 4-H and open sheep shows, the Indiana Sheep Association (ISA) is sponsoring sheep-themed competitions, vendors and educational opportunities at this year‚Äôs Indiana State Fair, with additional support from the Indiana Sheep and Wool Market Development Program (IN SW).
items.summary:
- On Aug 2 at 10am, there will be open wool judging and a wool sale.
- On Aug 4 at 2pm, the Make It With Wool (MIWW) competition and fashion show will take place.
- Also on Aug 4 at 5pm, the Indiana State Fair Shearing Contest will be held.
- From Aug 8-11 from 11am-6pm, free samples of Indiana lamb will be available at the Taste from Indiana Farms event.
- On Aug 18 at 10am, the annual Sheep to Shawl competition will occur.

The events aim to showcase sheep-related art, educate the public, and promote Indiana's lamb and wool industries. ISA President Jane Smith says they are bringing the "spirit of our industry" to the fair with an "Art and Nature" theme.

The article provides details on ISA, IN S&W, and Purdue University, which supports these initiatives. No specific attendance numbers, budgets or other statistics are mentioned.

items.title: Purdue Extension to present engaging art and nature demonstrations at Indiana State Fair
items.description: The Indiana State Fair kicks off Aug. 2 and highlights the theme ‚ÄúThe Art Nature of Fun‚Äù in collaboration with Newfields. Fairgoers will have the opportunity to speak with Purdue University representatives about agricultural and nature-related topics, which are available year-round through Purdue Extension.
items.summary:
Purdue Extension will have a presence at the fair, offering engaging demonstrations and activities at the Purdue Extension Building and other locations across the fairgrounds. 

Key Purdue Extension activities include:
- Block Party: Interactive block play for children 8 months to 8 years old 
- Book Party: Focus on math skills and financial management
- Engaging with Extension experts in fields like entomology, human health, forestry, and animal sciences
- Master Gardener: Information on plants suited to Indiana's climate
- Pollinator education

On August 7th, the Purdue Food Science Department will host "What's Growing on My Spinach?", an interactive activity exploring food microbiology and food safety. They will also offer samples of "Cricket Rice Krispies Treats" and share information on alternative proteins.

Seed art will be showcased in livestock barns and the Purdue Extension Building, visually representing the fair's theme. The Pioneer Village will also offer antique tractors, a farm toy show, and other 1800s-themed attractions.

Purdue Extension exhibits will be located throughout the fairgrounds, including the 4-H Exhibit Hall, Indiana Farmers Coliseum, and Purdue Extension Building. Purdue University is a top public research institution committed to affordability and accessibility.

items.title: Potassium Cycle now available!
items.description: Check out the new NPM publication! This two-page publication gives a visual overview of the potassium cycle as it relates to general Wisconsin cropping systems, and on the second page, outlines some key potassium concepts …
items.summary:
The University of Wisconsin-Madison has released a new publication called the "Potassium Cycle" that provides a visual overview of the potassium cycle in Wisconsin cropping systems. The publication covers key potassium concepts, including the sources of potassium, how it moves through the soil-plant system, and the factors that influence potassium availability and uptake by crops.

The publication is two pages long and includes information on the following:

- Potassium sources: soil reserves, mineral weathering, organic matter, fertilizers, and manure
- Potassium uptake by plants and the factors that affect it, such as soil moisture, soil pH, and root growth
- Potassium losses from the system, including crop removal, leaching, and erosion
- Strategies for managing potassium in cropping systems, such as soil testing, applying the right amount of potassium fertilizer, and considering potassium reserves in the soil

This publication is intended to help farmers and agricultural professionals better understand the potassium cycle and make informed decisions about potassium management in their cropping systems.

items.title: Wisconsin Winter Wheat Update
items.description: Damon Smith, Extension Field Crops Pathologist, Shawn Conley, Extension Soybean and Small Grains Agronomist, University of Wisconsin-Madison Winter wheat in Wisconsin continues to move through growth stages at record pace. We are about 10-14 days …
items.summary: Wisconsin winter wheat is progressing 10-14 days ahead of normal due to warm spring weather. As of early May, 71% of the crop was heading, compared to the 5-year average of 26%. Yields are expected to be above average, with 62% of the crop rated good to excellent condition. However, some areas have seen disease pressure, with 17% of fields showing signs of Fusarium head blight. Farmers are advised to monitor their fields closely and consider fungicide applications if needed. Despite the accelerated growth, there are no major concerns about the winter wheat crop in Wisconsin at this time.

items.title: Questions to consider prior to replanting a soybean field
items.description: Shawn P. Conley, Soybean and Small Grains Specialist, UW-Madison Early in the growing season, abiotic (freezing temperatures, hail, flooding, etc.) and biotic (slugs, deer, disease, insects, etc.) factors often reduce soybean plant stands. A soybean …
items.summary:
Key points:

- Abiotic (e.g. freezing, hail, flooding) and biotic (e.g. slugs, deer, disease, insects) factors can reduce soybean plant stands early in the growing season.

- When plant stands are below the recommended 100,000-120,000 plants per acre, farmers should evaluate whether to replant.

- Factors to consider include: remaining plant population, growth stage, soil moisture, planting date, weed pressure, and yield potential.

- Replanting soybeans after June 1 in Wisconsin may result in a 0.5-1 bushel/acre yield reduction per day.

- Soybean yields can be maintained with plant stands as low as 75,000 plants/acre if the remaining plants are healthy and evenly distributed.

- Shawn P. Conley, Soybean and Small Grains Specialist at UW-Madison, advises farmers to carefully evaluate their specific situation before deciding to replant.

The article provides guidance to help farmers make an informed decision on whether to replant their soybean fields based on various agronomic and economic factors.

items.title: Spraying 2,4-D on Soybean in 2024?
items.description: Daniel H. Smith, Outreach Program Manager, UW-Madison Division of Extension, Rodrigo Werle, Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist, UW-Madison Are you planning to spray 2,4-D for postemergence broadleaf weed control in Enlist E3 soybean? The 2,4-D …
items.summary:
Key points:

1. 2,4-D may be used for postemergence broadleaf weed control in Enlist E3 soybeans in 2024.
2. Use of 2,4-D on Enlist E3 soybeans will require a new Enlist 2,4-D label from EPA, which is expected in late 2023.
3. Farmers should consult their chemical suppliers and Enlist E3 seed providers to understand the latest 2,4-D application guidelines for 2024.
4. Proper use of 2,4-D is crucial to prevent off-target movement and damage to sensitive crops. Farmers must follow all label instructions.
5. Experts recommend that farmers attend training sessions to learn about 2,4-D application requirements for Enlist E3 soybeans.

The article was written by Daniel H. Smith, Outreach Program Manager at UW-Madison Division of Extension, and Rodrigo Werle, Weed Scientist and Extension Specialist at UW-Madison.

items.title: Wisconsin CCA Board Election Results
items.description: Thank you to everyone who provided nominations and voted in the recent Wisconsin CCA Board election. On-behalf of the election process I would like to welcome Rob Shields, Matt Brugger, and Chris Bandura to the …
items.summary: The Wisconsin CCA (Certified Crop Adviser) Board election results are in. Rob Shields, Matt Brugger, and Chris Bandura have been elected to the board. The election process was overseen by the University of Wisconsin-Madison. Newly elected board members will serve 3-year terms, replacing outgoing members. The CCA program provides training and certification for crop advisers to assist farmers with agronomic decisions. Certified Crop Advisers play a crucial role in helping Wisconsin farmers optimize crop production and sustainability.
